Our staff members analyze their work at the end of a school-year and plan their learning activities according to their needs. Traditionally individual meetings are held by the school administration with each of the staff, where they discuss the plans and needs for retraining and advancement. A training program is made up at IVVEC every school-year. The participation of the staff in EU mobilities is vastly supported by the school administration. IVVEC has long-term international experience in organizing mobilities for both staff and learners.  
The objective of the project is to implement a two-year project of high-quality mobilities which will enable the learners and staff of IVVEC to be more competitive. Both in Estonia and abroad the Centre will be positioned as one offering the best learning conditions to students and supporting the professional growth of its staff. Besides, the international cooperation grows more active.      
The learners, participating in the project, are the best second- and third-year students in 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 academic years in the following vocations: multimedia, junior software developers, IT system specialist, chef, pastry-chef, tourism management, carpenter, welder, machine-tool worker, electrician, auto technician, mechatronic, automatic, finishing works in construction, hair-dresser, logistics. 110 trainees are placed for practice at enterprises, 38 trainees – at VET schools and 38 VET workers will go learning / job-shadowing at the partner schools and companies. The partners for this application are in the following states: Latvia, Lithuania, Finland, Sweden, the UK, Hungary, Germany, Portugal, France, Austria, Spain and Slovenia. IVVEC has cooperated with most of the partners for many years.   
The preparation of the project has been carried out by a project team who has worked very closely and intensively with the partner organizations. The project application has been prepared in cooperation with the partners and the mobilities have been planned in accordance with their best learning conditions.
Thorough planning definitely serves a solid ground for successful project implementation. If funding granted, the project management team will be made up to implement the project in cooperation with the partners. The selection of the best candidates is carried out in accordance with the special procedure adopted at IVVEC. The staff members have already expressed their wish to study abroad. All the activities are documented which also guarantees the project implementation in case of unexpected changes in the project management team.
The opportunity to undertake independently a training placement abroad for students who come to study at IVVEC after both basic and secondary schools, enables them to grow more competitive both in Estonian and European job markets and gain more foreign language skills. The opportunity to have a practice placement abroad motivates the first- and second-year students to study harder. The knowledge and skills of the participating staff grows as well as their competence in advancing the apprenticeship system at IVVEC, which definitely have positive effect on the learners' motivation to study and reducing the drop-out rate.  Being abroad the participants have a great opportunity to get acquainted with foreign culture which brings to higher tolerance and respect towards it.   
All the mobility participants are issued a Europass Mobility and all the learning outcomes and assessments in different learning environments are taken into account and properly registered at IVVEC.
The successful international projects and their implementation make vocational education more popular in the region, creates a solid ground to raise the quality of education and attract more basic school graduates to study at IVVEC. According to the youth who enter IVVEC to study, as well as their parents, the opportunity to practice abroad is of utmost importance. The staff also highly estimates the opportunity to learn from colleagues at partner schools.   
We adhere to the principles of Skills Year 2017: value the skills, mastery, vocational education and lifelong learning. We appreciate the skills that help us to adapt in a rapidly changing world and have successful career.

De Rooi Pannen is a vocational school who takes care of quality education.  An enterprising attitude of students is one of the most important goals. A professional attitude and great social skills are necessary to become a successful enterpriser.  To enquire competences  De Rooi Pannen recognizes the importance of an internship abroad for the students and tries to stimulates this. Some foreign companies find it diffucult to give students an allowance for their internship. This is the reason not every student can go aboad. The Erasmus+ program enables an internship abroad for all students.   
Promotion from Erasmus+ program gives 63 student a traineeship in a companie abroad so they can orientate on the international labourmarket. The student acquires a beter vision of his future labour, knows where his occupation stands on the international labourmarket and enhences his language skills. Students develop independence and their adulthood grows. 
The students work in a hotel, camping, leisure sector, warehouse or commercial services and make assignments. 
The competences obtained by traineeship in a companie abroad makes it possible to gradute successful with higher results.  Students share their international experence insite and outsit school.  Insite school they provide information to students who want to go abroad, in order to have these students better prepared for their traineeship abroad. Outsite school students share their international experience by promotional activities (an article in a promotional flyer and to give information to potential students).

Professionalisation of teachers is part of policy of al department from De Rooi Pannen. Financial support by the Erasmus+  program stimulates to apply for Staff Training Abroad for 22 teachers in 2 years. 
Content & Language Integrated Learning (CLIL) enlarges English language level and anables new teaching methods. This makes it possible to professionalize bilingual education. 
Jobshadowing to a vocational institute abroad, which is specialized in events, enrises the knowledge to work with practial assignments. This knowlegde is valuable to integrate in the curriculum. 

For 20 students is VET learners traineeship in vocational institutes abroad applied. Annually 10 students Marketing & Events get the opportunity to distinguish by making a international study trip targeting language teaching in an international vocational institute. Selection is based on motivation. The combination of language teaching and contact with international students enhances the languages competence and the intercultural competence . 

The Erasmus+ program encourages to enlarge international contacts in the different sectors and improves the connection between  curriculum and the international labourmarket. This improves the quality of the education which enables the opportunity for enlarge traineeships abroad.

Not Just Numbers: Migration and Asylum Issues in Youth Work
 
Not Just Numbers is an international youth worker mobility project aimed at strengthening cooperation and developing capacity of youth organisations in dealing with migration and asylum issues.
 
The project is built on a needs analysis conducted by members of partner organisations in their communities and responds directly to needs and problems of their target groups – young people, notably those with fewer opportunities.
 
The project aims to improve the quality of local activities in the fields of migration and asylum awareness conducted by consortium members in their countries. Specific objectives of the project are: to facilitate exchange of expertise on approaches to migration and asylum education in youth work, to train youth workers in using education tools developed by UNHCR and the Red Cross (‘Not Just Numbers’ and ‘Positive Images’), to promote international cooperation and networking between youth organisations. 
 
The project’s main activity is an eight-day training programme (training of trainers) for 24 participants (youth workers) from six countries. The training will be held in Turku, Finland.
 
The project’s direct impact will be the increased capacity of partner organisations in addressing migration and asylum issues in youth work, increased skills of youth workers, raising awareness of migration and asylum rights and increased co-operation of youth organisations.
 
The project’s outputs, leading to a long-term impact, will be disseminated at two levels: locally by consortium members and Europe-wide by the project communications team. Dissemination measures will include local events involving young people, youth workers and other relevant stakeholders, in co-operation with local traditional media, as well as online dissemination tools including social media and websites.
Higher education student and staff mobility project
This is a higher education student and staff mobility project, please consult the website of the organisation to obtain additional details.
Arbeiten und Lernen in Europa - Internationales Praktikum der Beruflichen Schulen Untertaunus

The project is aimed at young people in a vocational school and commercial training with an emphasis on languages. During their internship in the host countries,  the students will get the chance to put their practical and theoretical  knowledge into operation in a foreign company using their selected target language. The participants have an  average educational achievement level of education and are in the middle of a vocational training affected by indirect or direct future unemployment on a labour market  on which any additional qualification increases  the prospect of employment. 
On the one hand the participants have been academically prepared in the relevant subjects at school to perform their internships well, on the other hand an external native speakers will familiarize them with specific features of the host country to eliminate  stumbling blocks before they occur and influence the internship negatively.

The participants go through a selective process which determines their suitability and is  intended to prevent premature termination of the internship. 
At the same time we would like to make sure that the motivation is real and a personal contribution i.e. commitment is expected. 
The main coordinator is in contact with all foreign partners and informs them about the skills of the participants, clarifies the possibilities of monitoring on site and defines the expectation horizon of the participants. Similarly  the opportunities for well elaborated and qualified evaluation of the internship will be clarified.
The participants will acquire knowledge in  foreign languages,  which would not be possible to acquire in the routine of a normal day at school, furthermore  they use their knowledge and skills in the foreign language and  thus gain confidence to tackle the next steps in their vocational  training successfully. An internship abroad is and will remain an important element both in life as well as  in the professional life of a young person.
The experiences gathered with people from other countries, even if in some cases the cultural backgrounds are only slightly different, structurally change the way of thinking about other people and countries and promote tolerance and solidarity with them.

Working together and the efforts concerning a common communication in a  mutual language create common ground that connects actors in problem-solving strategies and create acceptance of culturally and socially different  circumstances .
Formation professionnelle et culturelle de citoyens européens

Lycée Paul-Emile Victor is a medium-sized vocational school that is located in the suburbs of Angers in Western France and is easily accessible by tram or bus. It offers a mixed academic and vocational curriculum and delivers qualifications from NVQ to BTEC First in the industrial and tertiary fields (sales, retail, hospitality management, administration) to around 365 students. 
A European section in English was launched in 2014 in order to develop cultural, professional and linguistic skills among students. This section is directed towards targeting pupils who are motivated and who study BTEC courses in sales, retail, hospitality management and administration. The course deals with international business as well as cultural and linguistic enhancement. 
Various activities have been developed to help our students and ensure their progress and success. They are provided with schemes such as : mentoring or career guidance information day, they can visit local companies, they also have access to structures such as our school educational shop and company, they can take part in sports competitions, cultural projects, school trips abroad and even work placements in English-speaking countries.
Our school has always made every effort to foster student achievement. We believe that in order to respond to the labour market needs that requires an increased mobility, it is vital for our school to move forward to a more concrete and efficient international opening. That is why we have decided to: open a European section, to send some of our teachers abroad, to receive some teachers from other countries for job shadowing exchanges (CIEP), to welcome regularly language assistants, to join the tourism-related occupations campus, to organise school trips, and to take part in eTwinning projects. We fully intend to continue to these programs to further our students’ development and to help them pursue global-mindedness.
Furthermore, thanks to our first European mobility project with the Erasmus+ programme that started in 2016, and will end in June 2018, 19 of our students ( mainly from the European section) had the opportunity to do a three-week work placement in Canterbury (UK) during their final year. On average over the last two years, we were able to involve 10.5% of students who reached the final year in a mobility project in Europe. Hence, our school has actively contributed to the goals of the Europe 2020 strategy (six percent of students aged 18 to 34 who have received their diplomas should engage in a learning or a work placement programme abroad).
Within this new Erasmus+ project, we wish to go even further and offer a four-week work placement in Ireland to students from Year 12 (Première) and a three-week work placement to students from Year 13 (Terminale). Priority will be given to students who are part of the European section, while other students could join the project after an interview-selection process. We are prepared to continue our partnership with Canterbury until March 2019. However, as the UK prepares for the post-Brexit regulations, we may have to create a new partnership with an intermediary body in Dublin (Republic of Ireland) for the sake of practicality.
We aim to continue opening our students to the business world by allowing them to observe different professional practices in an English-speaking environment. This allows the student to prepare for the recruitment requirements after their BTEC (including HND training course) is completed, and also it helps them to integrate better into the world of work.
Our students will be able to: improve their communicating and professional skills in real-world situations, to develop new work experience, to enhance their fluency in English, to gain confidence and autonomy. By completing all of these aforementioned tasks in these work placements, the students will have strengthened their chances to become more employable.
The students will gain practical experience to expand their CV. According to the results obtained in examinations and during the work placement, they will receive certifications and recognition of their mobility abroad (Europass mobility, Euromobipro documents, the European section distinction on their BTEC diploma ….).
The staff involved in the programme will be given the chance to: get a better understanding of the British working methods and vocational training system in UK and Irish companies, to encourage other members of the school to participate in the programme, to develop European cooperation with their partners and the English tutors, and to reinforce interdisciplinary work and to maximize teaching methods.
As far as we are concerned, our vocational school will develop its international dimension at a local, academic, national and European level. We shall achieve it by motivating our students to participate in this programme so that they may see the need to learn English as a tool of communication in the modern world.
Higher education student and staff mobility project
This is a higher education student and staff mobility project, please consult the website of the organisation to obtain additional details.

Eight partners from Austria,  Great Britain, Spain, Sweden and Germany and 13 students aged between 16 and 17 as well as four teachers from the vocational college in Wolfsberg (in short HLW) are  involved in the project. This means that 13 out of 43 third grade students will participate in the Erasmus+ project supported by the European Union, and spend their three-month placement abroad.
They are all eligible to take part in the Erasmus+ programme because they have to do a three-month placement between the third and the fourth year of our school to be allowed to sit the final exams two years later. That´s why the school year ends for them at the end of May and starts again on the first Monday in October. They have to do their compulsory training within these four months.
At our school, there are two different focuses: 1. language and media and 2. wellness and health management. Most of the students have very good English skills as well as good Italian/French skills. Some of them have even attended optional subjects like Russian, wine-connoisseur, bar-keeper, patisserie, etc. 
During their placements abroad, students want to practise, strengthen as well as enlarge their practical as well as theoretical knowledge, which they have acquired in the first three years at our school. Furthermore, within this project, students will be given the chance to get to know a country which they might not know at all or only from a short holiday. Another important aim is to improve their language skills by making use of what they already know, internalizing it and expanding their vocabulary, etc. The latter will be supported by the OLS, Online Linguistic Support.
Which skills are to be focused on, will be put down in the Learning Agreements in accordance with teachers, employers and students. During the training (visits, reports from students and mentors), that is, afterwards - the achievement of these goals will be checked. Additional ECVET aspects included in the project are: Personal Transcript and Memorandum of Understanding which are to be signed in the course of visits in the respective countries. What´s new here are questionnaire in which partners are assessed by students. 
Taking part in this project is therefore useful for the students in many respects. By working in foreign countries they can consolidate, brush up and enlarge their practical as well as their language skills and thus significantly increase their chances on the job market. A further important aspect is that with the help of the Erasmus Plus project the students will crack prejudices, become more open-minded and tolerant. And last but not least, participants will become more mobile, even at an early age. 
The results of the project will be published in local and regional newspapers, the school website, the yearbook, on FB, etc. Moreover, experienced project participants will pass their knowledge on to students who are thinking of going abroad in the following year at informative events not only at school but also outside of it.
Staff mobility is another aspect that will be focused on again this year. Three teachers will do a job shadowing abroad, two at a school in Cuxhaven, Germany and one English/Spanish teacher at a school in Avila, Spain. The aims are to find out more about the school systems in the two countries and, of course, how classes work. What´s more, the two teachers who will spend a week at the German school want to find out more about the implementation of COOL (Cooperative Open Learning) in the classroom. This is something they are familiar with as well. Another thing they are interested in is the Theatre Company which they have had in Cuxhaven for year and is something we are aspiring to have as well.
The other teacher who is going to spend a week in Spain wants to form the basis for a future cooperation with the Spanish school, most likely in form of a School Exchange. By the way, this contact has its roots at Comenius training in Southampton where the Erasmus+ coordinator met a teacher from the Spanish school. A third visit is planned for Stockholm where two colleagues do a job-shadowing. HLW Wolfsberg, in return, is very much looking forward to welcoming representatives of the new partner schools in Wolfsberg.
And finally, the coordinator of this project wants to pay GB a final visit, also to find out if and how a cooperation between the two countries will be possible after BREXIT.
